title: Name of the last Heilung album
description: The name of the album is written with Elder Futhark on the cover. On the LP edition, each of the 4 sides is labelled with one of the runes.
explanationAfter: Good answer! The band themselves explain that Drif means "gathering".

title: Einangsteinen (Einang stone)
description: The Einang stone is located in Gardbergfeltet, a historical site in Oppland, Norway, holding over 550 burial mounds and over 900 discoveries from Roman Iron Age and Viking Age. The Einang stone is believed to date back to around 300 AD, and for a long time was the oldest known runic stone from northwestern Europe.
explanationAfter: Excellent! As explained by Kristel Zilmer on Twitter (see sources): Moltke's reading - still commonly accepted - is: …daga-(t)(i)R runo faihido. He suggested that the start could be: [Ek Go]dagastiR rūnō faihidō, «I, GodagastiR, painted (wrote) the rune (i.e. the runic inscription)”. The singular rūnō can refer to the overall runic message.

title: Svingerudsteinen (Svingerud Stone)
description: In early 2023, this stone was announced to be the oldest known runic inscription to date. It was found in a cremation ground, in Hole near Tyrifjorden, Eastern Norway, by University of Oslo researchers. The inscriptions are dated between 1 and 250 AD. The stone itself is a 31x32 cm block of reddish-brown Ringerike sandstone.
explanationAfter: Great answer! The inscription, consisting of thin, shallow runes, is transliterated as "Idiberug". According to Kristel Zilmer, professor at Oslo's Museum of Cultural History: this could be name of a woman Idibera or a kin named Idiberung.

title: Bergen stick B 149
description: The stick has an inscription on both sides, consisting of mixed long- and short-twig Younger Futhark runes. The first side says: ᚴᛦᛆ : ᛌᛅᚼᛁᚱ : ᛆᛐᚦᚢ : ᚴᛆᚴ : ᚼᛅᛁᛉ.
explanationAfter: Yes! That is the famous inscription which translates to "Gyða segir at þú gakk heim" - "Gyða tells you to go home"!

title: Grumpan bracteate Vg 207
description: Grumpan bracteate was found in Sweden and is dated to ca. 500-550 AD. It is kept in the Historiska Museet in Stockholm.
explanationAfter: Correct! This bracteate depicts the division of Elder Futhark row into 3 equal parts.

title: Gripsholm stone Sö 179
description: The Gripsholm Stone - which can to this day be visited near the Gripsholm Castle not far from Stockholm - is one of the "Ingvarr stones". This group of stones is dated soon after 1041, when the Icelandic annals record the death of Yngvarr the Far-Travelled in the south. Note how the inscriber forgot one word and added it later!
explanationAfter: Correct. The last part (from the word inserted later) runs: "Þæiʀ foru drængila, fjarri at gulli, auk austarla ærni gafu. Dou sunnarla, a Særklandi" -- "They went manfully, far after gold, and in the east gave [food] to the eagle [i.e. despatched enemies in battle]. They died in the south, in Særkland." (translation credit to Michael P. Barnes, p. 77 from Runes: A Handbook)
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 77-8, 81, 139, 169)

title: Kylver stone G 88
description: The Kylver stone originates from the Baltic island of Gotland. It is one of eleven known inscriptions of the older futhark row, dated to 5th and 6th centuries (only 4 of these 11 give the complete rune row order).
explanationAfter: Two things to note about the Kylver stone: 1) there is no division of the run row into the ættir - groups of eight - unlike for example the Grumpan bracteate; 2) the runes at positions 13-4 (ᛈ, ᛇ) and 23-4 (ᛞ, ᛟ) are given in the opposite order than usually.
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 16-19)

title: Jelling stone of Harald Bluetooth
description: A rune-stone with political themes from north-eastern Jutland. King Haraldr claims on it to have made himself master of all Denmark and of Norway. These are among the earliest occurrences of the names "Denmark" and "Norway". Thanks to the  political references, Jelling 2 stone can be fairly reliably dated to around 970-980s.
explanationAfter: The translation to be found in Barnes' book is as follows: "King Haraldr ordered [people] to make these monuments after GormR, his father and after Þorvi, his mother. That Haraldr who won for himself all Denmark, and Norway, and made the Danes Christian." ("Haraldr kunungR bað gørva kumbl þøsi aft Gorm, faður sin, ok aft Þórvi, moður sina. Sa Haraldr æs sæR vann Danmork alla ok Norvæg ok dani gærði kristna.")
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 73-4)

title: Ramsundberget carving Sö 101
description: The Ramsund carving is located in Södermanland, Sweden. The carving is almost 5m wide, making it the biggest known rune carving. It is unusual, since the carving is made in a flat rock, not in a standing stone.
explanationAfter: Good answer! The runes are believed to translate to "Sigriðr gærði bro þasi, moðiR Alriks, dottiR Orms, for salu HolmgæiRs, faður SigrøðaR, boanda sins." -- "Sigríðr, Alríkr's mother, Ormr's daughter, made this bridge for the soul of Holmgeirr, father of Sigrøðr, her husbandman".
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 84)

title: Kjølevik stone N KJ75
description: The Kjølevik stone is dated to 5th century and was found in Rogaland, south+western Norway.
explanationAfter: Old Norse translation of the inscription is believed to be "Haðulaikaz. Ek Hagustaldaz hlaiwiðdo magu minino" -- "Haðulaikaz. I Hagustaldaz buried my son". Haðulaikaz is a man's name consisting of elements "battle" ahnd "play".
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 30)

title: Burseryd baptismal font
description: This is 13th century baptismal font from Burseryd church in Småland, Sweden.
explanationAfter: Yes! Translation: "Arinbjorn gjørði mik. Vitkunder prester skref mik. Ok hær skal um stund standa" -- "Arinbjorn made me. Vitkunder the priest wrote me. And here I shall stand for a while". Interesting detail is the use of [th] instead of [þ] in the spelling of "gørthi". Note there are some bind runes, which in this exercise were split due to limitations of Unicode.
sources: Runes: A Handbook by Michael P. Barnes (p 102-3)

title: Maughold I stone
description: This runestone is dated to 1150-1199 and was found in the Maughold parish in the Isle of Man.
explanationAfter: Yes! According to Scandinavian Runic-text Database (see sources), the inferred transliteration is "(i)(u)an + brist + raisti + þasir + runur +¶ [f]uþor(k)(h)niastbml +". The translation to Old Norse is "Jóan prestr reisti þessar rúnar. <fuþorkhniastbml>" and to English: "Jóan the priest carved these runes. fuþorkhniastbml"

title: Ågedal bracteate N IK1
description: Little is known about this bracteate. It was found in southern Norway and contains inscriptions in Older Futhark, though with inconsistent direction of carving. It is made of gold and is dated before early 8th century.
explanationAfter: That's a correct transliteration of the intelligible symbols. Uppsala University website makes the following attempt at translation to Old Norse: "Þiz æje, i-rioð, i yhli-afl haha! Lið tiaðe elli aiga i tahe". English: "The slave-woman, rosy-cheeked, full of yule-power (=intoxicated), may lead the horse to the pasture! It became apparent that the old one had a retinue in the tún (=his own homestead)".
